event.doc_name: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: Case 2:22-cv-00368-NT   Document 1   Filed 11/21/22   Page 1 of 14    PageID #: 1
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: Plaintiffs assert claims for violation of their rights to Equal Protection (Count I) and Due Process (Count II) under the U.S. Constitution
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Equal Protection (Fifth Amendment)

evidence.text: Plaintiffs assert claims for violation of their rights to Equal Protection (Count I) and Due Process (Count II) under the U.S. Constitution and for violation of the federal Rehabilitation Act, 29 U.S.C. § 794 (Count III).
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794)

evidence.text: The exclusion of medically necessary surgeries for gender transition in Section 1079, and its application and enforcement by the Defendants, violates the Equal Protection guarantee of the Fifth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Fifth Amendment - Equal Protection

evidence.text: The exclusion of surgeries for 'sex gender change' in Section 1079, and its application and enforcement by the Defendants, are arbitrary and capricious and lack any rational basis... Through the application and enforcement of the exclusion in Section 1079, Defendants have violated the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Fifth Amendment - Due Process

evidence.text: The Defendants are subject to the nondiscrimination provisions of 29 U.S.C. § 794 which apply to 'all DoD Components and recipients of federal financial assistance disbursed by a DoD Component insofar as the programs and activities of the DoD Components and recipients affect handicapped persons in the United States.'
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794)

evidence.text: 1. Issue a declaratory judgment that the exclusion of surgeries for 'sex gender change' in 10 U.S.C. Section 1079(a)(11), including the categorical exclusion of surgical treatments for gender dysphoria, is unconstitutional and violates Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act;
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff: Declaratory judgment that exclusion in 10 U.S.C. § 1079(a)(11) is unconstitutional and violates Rehabilitation Act

evidence.text: 2. Issue a permanent injunction prohibiting the Defendants, their agents, employees, representatives, contractors or any third party acting on their behalf from any enforcement or application of the exclusion of surgeries for 'sex gender change' in 10 U.S.C. § 1079(a)(11), including surgeries for gender dysphoria, through regulations, policies or any other means, and directing Defendants to provide TRICARE coverage for Plaintiff Jane Doe's medically necessary gender affirming surgical procedures;
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff: Permanent injunction prohibiting enforcement of exclusion in 10 U.S.C. § 1079(a)(11)

evidence.text: 3. Award Plaintiffs damages in an amount to be established at trial;
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff: Damages

evidence.text: 4. Award Plaintiffs their reasonable attorneys’ fees, costs and expenses pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 1088 or other applicable statutes;
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff: Attorneys' fees and costs

evidence.text: The Plaintiffs are two transgender women who receive health insurance through the United States military’s TRICARE program (“TRICARE”) as dependents of former servicemembers. The Defendants are TRICARE itself and three parties responsible for implementing and overseeing it: the U.S. Secretary of Defense Lloyd J. Austin, III; the U.S. Department of Defense; and the U.S. Defense Health Agency.
evidence.source_document: Order on Cross-Motions for Summary Judgment

add_extracted.value: Plaintiffs Jane Doe and Susan Roe, transgender women receiving TRICARE as dependents of former servicemembers, allege TRICARE's exclusion of gender transition surgeries violates Fifth Amendment Equal Protection rights
